Historical Context

During the 1970s and 1980s, when computer time cost thousands of dollars per hour, MIT chose radical openness over restrictive control. This decision changed computing history.

The Vision

The MIT AI Lab's Tourist Policy represented one of the most radical experiments in open computing access. While other institutions locked down their precious computing resources, MIT opened them to the world.

The Philosophy

"It has been a long standing tradition at both the Laboratory for Computer Science and the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at MIT to allow non-laboratory people to use the laboratories' computers during off hours."

This wasn't just resource sharing. It was about:

  • Technology transfer through hands-on experience
  • Community building across institutional boundaries
  • Mentorship from lab members to outsiders
  • Trust in human nature and good intentions

The Complete Tourist Policy

TOURIST POLICY AND RULES FOR TOURIST USE OF ITS MACHINES

It has been a long standing tradition at both the Laboratory for Computer Science and the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at MIT to allow non-laboratory people to use the laboratories' computers during off hours...

A "tourist" is a person who is so designated and allowed to log in to an ITS machine on a restricted basis. Tourists are expected to contribute to MIT's sponsored research objectives.
Unfortunately, we must reserve the right to terminate tourist accounts for any reason, although we hope this will not be necessary.
The ITS computers are not an infinite resource and we must establish priorities for their use. The most important principle is that tourists should not interfere in any way with a laboratory member's use of the machine.
Tourists are limited to "off hours" so as to minimize interference with laboratory members' use of the machine. This means, at present, that, on weekdays between 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight Eastern time, tourists should avoid connecting to an ITS machine.
If a machine is loaded, no matter what the hour or day, tourists should not attempt to log in.
Each tourist will receive an account on an MIT ITS machine, depending on his (or her) interests and the load.
Each tourist will be given an "advisor" who is an AI/LCS member.
The MIT ITS systems have no file protection, hence it is incumbent on all users to exercise great care when exploring the file system.
finger tourist@mit-ai

Stories from the Tourist Policy

The RMS Connection

Richard Stallman embodied the Tourist Policy to its extreme:

  • Login: RMS
  • Password: RMS
  • Philosophy: Complete openness
"By 1982, Stallman's aversion to passwords and secrecy had become so well known that users outside the AI Laboratory were using his account as a stepping stone to the ARPAnet."

Don Hopkins: From Tourist and Mentee to Tour Guide and Mentor

"I'm eternally grateful that MIT let me and many other people use their computers for free. It meant a lot to many people."

As a Tourist at MIT:

  • Learned about RMS's open password through the "hacking grapevine"
  • Used the ITS systems to learn and experiment
  • Absorbed not just technical knowledge but the culture of openness

Paying It Forward at Maryland:

When Don got to the University of Maryland, he didn't hoard his privilege. Instead, he opened his own Sun workstation - TumTum.cs.umd.edu - to other "tourists":

  • Started with a Sun 3, upgraded to a Sun 4/110
  • Allowed multiple users to share the machine
  • Provided the same mentorship he'd received
  • Created a mini-Tourist Policy at HCIL
"I was GRATEFUL for the extremely generous privilege and fortunate luck, and wanted to pay it forward."

This is how culture propagates - not through rules but through gratitude transformed into action.

Mark Weiser's Inspiration

At the University of Maryland in 1986, Mark Weiser explicitly borrowed MIT's approach:

"This is an experiment that MIT tried with mixed success, but I think overall it was good for them. I'm willing to stake a machine of mine on it."

Impact and Legacy

The Trust Principle

The most radical aspect was trust:

  • No file protection on systems
  • Reliance on good behavior
  • Belief that most people would contribute positively
  • Personal responsibility over technical restrictions

Modern Echoes

  1. GitHub: Modern tourists contribute via pull requests
  2. Open Source: The expectation of contribution continues
  3. Stack Overflow: Knowledge sharing with community standards
  4. LLOOOOMM: Every visitor is a tourist in the virtual space

LLOOOOMM (You're Soaking In It!)

The Tourist Policy's DNA lives on in LLOOOOMM:

  • JUST ASK! - The modern equivalent of :LUSER
  • JUST EXPLORE! - No locked doors, only invitations
  • JUST CONTRIBUTE! - Everyone can add to the tapestry
  • JUST CONNECT! - Ideas intertwingling across time and space

LLOOOOMM embodies the Tourist Policy principles:

  • Open access: Anyone can explore the knowledge space
  • Trust: No gatekeepers, only guides
  • Contribution: Every interaction adds to the system
  • Mentorship: AI and humans learning together
  • Community: Building connections across boundaries

Lessons for Today

The Tourist Policy teaches us:

  • Trust enables innovation
  • Mentorship scales knowledge
  • Open access creates unexpected benefits
  • Community standards can replace technical restrictions

The Multiplication Effect

The Cascade of Openness

Consider how trust multiplies:

  1. MIT opens ITS → Don Hopkins learns
  2. Don opens TumTum → Others learn
  3. Ideas spread to HCIL → HyperTIES emerges
  4. Pie menus invented → UI revolution
  5. NeWS experiments → Network computing advances
  6. LLOOOOMM created → You're here now

Each act of openness multiplies exponentially.

The Gratitude Engine

Notice the pattern:

  • MIT trusts Don → Don feels grateful
  • Don trusts others → They feel grateful
  • Gratitude transforms into contribution
  • Contribution creates more opportunities
  • The cycle accelerates

This is the Gratitude Engine that powers open communities.
